docs.lead_paragraph: In October, a judge here imposed a six-month sentence on a 21-year-old pregnant woman who pleaded guilty to forgery and asserted that the penalty was an effort to prevent her from having an abortion. On Monday, the woman, Yuriko Kawaguchi, gave birth to a girl in San Francisco, her lawyer said.

headline.main: National News Briefs; Girl Is Born to Ex-Inmate Who Sued Over Abortion

docs.abstract: Judge Patricia Cleary in Oct 1998 sentenced Yuriko Kawaguchi, who was pregnant, to six months in prison for forgery, and asserted that penalty was effort to prevent her from having abortion; Kawaguchi was arrested in May in connection with credit card forgery scheme in Cleveland; she gave birth to girl in San Francisco on Feb 1 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: First it was ''Chicago Hope.'' In the fall of 1994, while others went straight for NBC's ''E.R.,'' with its hot young cast of medical students and residents, I chose instead the hospital across town, on CBS, where the doctors were more seasoned. Adam Arkin as the neurosurgeon, Mandy Patinkin as the cardiac surgeon: a perfect balance of head and heart. There were the life-and-death stories that have been staples of prime-time medical dramas since the days of ''Ben Casey'' and ''Dr. Kildare,'' but the real suspense lay in what would prompt Mr. Patinkin's character to break into song. Soon ''Chicago Hope'' was moved to Monday (and since to Wednesday), conceding Thursdays to ''E.R.,'' which instantly became a hit series. Two hours of hospital crises a week! My inner hypochondriac couldn't have been happier.

headline.main: Comprehensive Medical Coverage, at Your Fingertips

docs.abstract: Three hourlong drama series about doctors and their patients are hits with television viewers; they are Chicago Hope on CBS, ER on NBC, and LA doctors on CBS; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A day after United Nations scientists reported that mother-to-infant transmission of the AIDS virus could be significantly cut by a new, simple drug treatment regimen, serious questions about its safety arose from a report of the deaths of two babies in a similar, separate French study. Both babies died from a rare neurological disease, French scientists reported at a meeting here today.

headline.main: Babies' Deaths Raise Fear Over AIDS Therapy

docs.abstract: Report that mother-to-infant transmission of AIDS virus can be significantly cut by simple drug treatment regimen is called into question by separate French report on death of two babies from rare neurological disease; disease has not been noted among babies who received drugs in US studies; UN scientists issued first report at AIDS meeting in Chicago; organizers allegedly did not permit release of report on two cases until day later; UN Dr Joseph Saba says overall benefit could still outweigh risks (S)
docs.snippet: A day after United Nations scientists reported that mother-to-infant transmission of the AIDS virus could be significantly cut by a new, simple drug treatment regimen, serious questions about its safety arose from a report of the deaths of two babies...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the first sex discrimination case under the Federal Family and Medical Leave Act, a jury awarded $375,000 to a Maryland state trooper who said he was refused extended leave to care for his newborn daughter because he is male. The trooper, Kevin Knussman, a helicopter paramedic, said his supervisors refused to give him extended leave under either the Federal law, which gives workers up to 12 weeks of parental leave, or a Maryland law that allows ''primary care providers'' up to 30 days of paid leave after the birth or adoption of a baby.

headline.main: Father Awarded $375,000 In a Parental Leave Case

docs.abstract: Maryland jury, in first sex discrimination case under Federal Family and Medical Leave Act, awards $375,000 to Maryland state trooper who said he was refused extended leave to care for newborn daughter because he is male; Kevin Knussman, helicopter paramedic, charged supervisors denied him leave under either Federal or state law, telling him he could not be primary care giver unless 'your wife is in a coma or dead,' and because he cannot breast feed; Knussman returned to work in December 1994 under threat of dismissal; case was cited by Pres Clinton and in Hillary Clinton's book It Takes a Village; photo of Knussmans and their daughters (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On the most obvious level, Schubert's song cycle ''Winterreise'' tells of a spurned lover's wanderings in aimless despair through a wintry clime: a winter of the soul, it soon becomes obvious, more than of the external elements. Rather than inveigh against nature for his agonies, the wanderer bemoans any brightening of the atmosphere for the illusory hopes it engenders. On a deeper level, ''Winterreise'' is about alienation more generally. ''I arrived a stranger/A stranger I depart,'' runs the opening couplet of the first song, ''Good Night.'' In the concluding ''Organ Grinder,'' the wanderer finally establishes a community of feeling, with a hapless old beggar: ''No one wants to listen,/No one looks at him,/And the dogs growl/Around the old man.''
docs.abstract: James R Oestreich reviews recital by Thomas Quasthoff, 39-year-old German bass-baritone, singing Schubert's Winterreise at Alice Tully Hall; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: United Nations scientists reported here today that a new, simple and relatively inexpensive drug treatment program can significantly reduce mother-to-infant transmission of the AIDS virus. The results are not as good as those from the standard treatment in Western countries, where prospective mothers infected with the virus receive the drug AZT daily, starting at about the 26th week of pregnancy, and their babies take it for the first six weeks of life.

headline.main: Spare AIDS Regime Is Found To Reduce Risk to Newborns

docs.abstract: UN scientists say new, simple and relatively inexpensive drug treatment program can significantly reduce mother-to-infant transmission of AIDS virus; say new strategy, in which mother takes two pills daily, is not as effective as expensive standard treatment that uses azidothymidine (AZT), but greatly abbreviates treatment period; study, conducted in three African countries, is reportedly largest ever performed of mother-to-child HIV transmission; researcher Dr Joseph Saba, who reported findings, comments (M)
docs.snippet: United Nations scientists reported here today that a new, simple and relatively inexpensive drug treatment program can significantly reduce mother-to-infant transmission of the AIDS virus.    The results are not as good as those from the standard...

docs.lead_paragraph: The life of Rashida, a shy young Moroccan woman, has a medieval ring to it. She sleeps on the floor of a small, dank room inside the compound of a fish cannery in Agadir. She may be summoned to work at any hour, even two in the morning, depending on when the fishing fleet comes in. For less than five dollars a day, she plods in a big rubber apron surrounded by a piercing stench, scaling and gutting pile after pile of sardines and anchovies. But Rashida, who is 23, considers herself lucky.

headline.main: Agadir Journal; After the Rape, a Lifetime of Shame. It's Morocco.

docs.abstract: Article on plight of unwed mothers in Morocco who, with children, live as outcasts in country's conservative Islamic society; women, regarded as inferior under country's Koranic laws, are treated with even greater disdain if they give birth to children out of wedlock; pregnant girls, even when very young or have been raped, are commonly thrown out by families who say they bring dishonor, and Govt or religious charities provide no support; plight of unwed mothers in Agadir discussed; photo; map (M)
